metadata.title: Obesity as a Predictor for a Poor Prognosis of COVID-19: A 1 Systematic Review

abstract.text: Cochrane, MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PubMed. The identified articles were screened 38 using the chosen eligibility criteria. We obtained three retrospective cohort studies 39 (Wu J et al., Lighter J et al., and Simonnet A et al.) to be critically appraised using 40 Newcastle Ottawa Scale. 41 Results: The findings of all included studies were consistent in stating the 42 contribution of obesity as a risk factor to increase the requirement for advanced 43 medical care. Study with the highest quality, Simonnet A et al., reported an increase 44 need of invasive mechanical ventilation in COVID-19 patients with body mass index 45

higher than 35 kg/m 2 , OR: 7.36 (1.63-33.14; p=0.021). This systematic 49 review highlights a particularly vulnerable group -obese, and emphasises on the 50 importance of treatment aggression and disease prevention in this population group. 51 52 Keywords: COVID-19, obesity, prognosis, predictor 53 54 sample size, BMI and presence of other comorbidities). However, unlike Simonnet A 178 study, the inclusion of other important comorbidities in multivariate analysis in 179 Lighter J study was not known [19]. 180 Furthermore, a careful interpretation of studies by Lighter J and Wu J should 181 be made due to the use of different comparator group. Studies by Lighter J and Wu 182 J compared the data of obese groups with both normo-and over-weight groups, 183 whereas Simonnet A study compared the obese with normoweight patients. Obesity has been associated with impaired immune system, increasing the 34 susceptibility for 2019-nCoV infection. We aimed to study the impact of obesity to 35 the prognosis and disease severity of COVID-19. 36

Coronavirus disease-2019 / COVID-19 is a new emerging pandemic. Its rapid 56 transmission, progressivity and high case fatality rate had affected global social 57 welfare and economy [2] . Per 25 April 2020, the total confirmed coronavirus cases 58 globally reached 2,902,708 along with 202,179 death [1] . 59

body_text.text: The prognosis of COVID-19 has been consistently reported to worsen in 60 advanced age [3, 4] and with the presence of other comorbidities, such as 61 hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, diabetes mellitus, and pulmonary diseases 62

Nevertheless, the growing rate of hospitalization in younger population has 63 been reported and associated with obesity [7,8], a condition of having excessive 64 adipose tissue. The growing prevalence of obesity globally have risen the concern 65 on its additional impact to worsen this pandemic [11] . 66

body_text.text: Obesity has been associated with a condition of chronic inflammation and 67 Hence, we aim to investigate the impact of obesity to the requirement of 75 advanced medical treatment in positively-identified COVID-19 patients, with the 76 hypothesis of obesity being a poor prognostic factor for COVID-19. Data from each study was extracted in a standardised form, compiling study citations, 100 baseline characteristics of the included subjects, appropriate intervention, and the 101 study findings. Study citations included the name of the first author, year of 102 publication, and title of the study. body_text.text: Data was synthesised based on a minimum of three different and high-quality 117 studies with consistent finding. The obtained data was analysed considering the 118 method of variable analysis used, study size, odds/hazard ratio, along with its 119 confidence interval. 120

body_text.text: Literature searching performed using keywords as listed in Table 1 yielded several 123 studies. Out of 573 articles identified, 18 articles were retrieved after title and 124 abstract screening. After the exclusion of duplicates, five studies were assessed in 125 full-text. Three studies remained after full-text screening using eligibility criteria, 126 which were studies by Wu J et al.
[17], Lighter J et al. [18] , and Simonnet A et al.
[19]. The exclusion of the remaining two studies was due to the usage of language 128 other than English/Indonesian and investigation on other types of coronaviruses. 129
The flow of our study selection is presented according to PRISMA Statement ( Figure  130 1). 131

stratified their study subjects by their age, dividing them into less than 60 years and 145 over 60 years age-groups. Compared to normo-and over-weight groups, the rate of 146 hospitalization increased 2.0 (1.6-2.6; p<0.0001) and 2.2 (1.7-2.9; p<0.0001) times 147 in younger patient group with obesity grade I and II, respectively. Moreover, 148 younger group patients with obesity grade I and II had an increased likelihood to 149 receive critical care 1.8 (1.2-2.7; p<0.006) and 3.6 (2.5-5.3; p<0.0001) times 150 respectively, compared to normoweight and overweight groups [18] . Study by Wu J In the aspect of sample size, study by Lighter J et al. was very precise with 173 their findings statistically [18] . Meanwhile, study by Simonnet A, the highest quality considered obesity not as an independent risk factor for COVID-19 disease severity 187

Article with the highest quality was written by Simonnet et al [19] . Although The limitations of this study arise from the exclusion of articles written in 231 languages other than English and Indonesian and unexplored grey literatures. We 232 also failed to assess the baseline characteristics and variable analysis of Lighter J 233 article. Moreover, this systematic review could not be proceeded to a quantitative 234 analysis (meta-analysis) due to the heterogenous use of variable analysis. Thus, we 235 recommended future studies to adjust comorbidities to their risk ratio presentation 236 to clearly portray the effect of obesity to the disease severity of COVID-19. 237

Taken together, this is the first systematic review to proclaim obesity as an 238 independent risk and prognostic factor for the requirement of advanced medical 239 treatment due to COVID-19. Hence, the results from this study are important in the 240 aspect of treatment aggression and disease prevention. Obese patients with COVID-241 19 should be treated as a higher risk population. In the aspect of prevention, while 242 staying home has been campaigned globally to reduce COVID-19 rapid transmission, 243 in long term, it may simultaneously increase the susceptibility of people to develop

FIGREF0.text: Aims: COVID-19 is an emerging pandemic due to droplet 31 infection of 2019-novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV). Due to its rapid transmission and 32

FIGREF1.text: decreased immune system, increasing the susceptibility of an individual to 68 infections [12,13]. Hence, this evidence suggests that obesity might act as an 69 independent risk factor for a poor disease progression of COVID-19. Nevertheless, a 70 meta-analysis by Ni Y (2017) reported the protective factor of obesity in Acute 71 Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) patients [14]. Having ARDS as one of the 72 devastating clinical manifestations of COVID-19 [4], this contradicting views raises 73 doubts on the impact of obesity in the disease severity and prognosis of COVID-19.

FIGREF3.text: 151 et al. also reported an increased risk of 1.30 (1.09-1.54; p=0.003) times in COVID-is a devastating infectious disease worldwide, commonly manifests in 158 acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) [4]. Its rapid transmission and 159 considerably high case-fatality rate have called for the recognition of important risk 160 factors and high-risk population for better prevention and treatment approach. 161 Obesity has been speculated to act independently in increasing the risk and 162 worsening the prognosis of COVID-19 patients. In this systematic review, three 163 included studies are consistent, despite a moderate degree of variability, in showing 164 the deleterious effect of obesity in COVID-19 severity, inducing critical and advanced 165 hospital care. 166 The findings from the included studies acknowledged the increased risk of 167 COVID-19 severity in obesity. Nevertheless, those three studies reported a variable 168 degree of association between obesity and severe COVID-19, which might be related 169 to the differences in the definition of the reported outcome (invasive mechanical 170 ventilation, ICU admission, severe infection), comparator group, sample size, and to 171 a lesser extent, the use of different BMI cut off points for obesity. 172

FIGREF4.text: its sample size was the smallest among them, this research included multivariate 191 analysis to omit the possibilities of other important comorbidities affecting the study 192 outcome. Different to other prognostic studies, this study did not differentiate the 193 mortality rate of obese and non-obese patients; hence, might not directly reflect a 194 poorer prognosis of disease severity in obese COVID-19 patients. Nevertheless, a 195 paper by Yang X et al. showed higher mortality rate of patients requiring mechanical 196 ventilation [4]. Thus, choosing the necessity of mechanical ventilation in obese 197 COVID-19 might be an appropriate outcome to assess prognosis and hospital cost. 198 Possible mechanisms related to disease severity in obesity are speculated to 199 occur through higher ACE-2 concentration, chronic inflammation, and functional 200 restrictive capacity of obese lung. ACE-2 receptor has been recognised as a 201 coreceptor for 2019-nCoV entry and known to be expressed in many parts of human 202 body: gastrointestinal tract, lung, heart and kidney [20]. A recent publication has 203 reported the increased expression of ACE-2 receptor in adipose tissue [21]. This 204 means having more adipocytes is equal to be having more ACE-2 receptors to catch 205 2019-nCoV. Moreover, chronic inflammation in obesity is apparent with the 206 increased interleukin 6 (IL-6) level, adipokines, and pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., 207 TNF-a, inferferon), inducing a chronic low-grade inflammatory state in obesity and 208 impairing immune response [12,13,19]. The total lung capacity has also been 209 reported to be reduced in obese patients, and improved by bariatric surgery [22,23]. 210 Moreover, a study by Campos et al. also emphasised the impact of obesity to reduce 211 lung function in sedentary subjects [23]. Hence, obese patients tend to be more 212 susceptible to COVID-19 infection and rapid severe disease progression due to its 213 lower baseline lung functional capacity than normoweight people. 214 On the other hand, a meta-analysis by Ni Y et al. (2017) reported the fluid or vasopressor requirement in circulatory failure [14]. This condition was 219 thought to contribute to a diminished potential of disease progression to ARDS. 220 However, Ni Y study made no attempt to explain the direct effect of obesity and 221 ARDS, in contrast to the previous explanation through molecular and lung functional 222 capacity changes in obesity. Hence, our study also shed light on the contrasting view 223 of ARDS and obesity. The severity of ARDS and overall COVID-19 clinical 224 manifestations increased in obese patients infected with COVID-19 and this 225 population even showed a higher need of invasive mechanical ventilation [19]. 226 Findings from COVID-19 which were discussed in this study were also in line with 227 previous coronaviruses studies: coronavirusHKU1[24] and MERS-CoV virus [25]. 228 These studies had previously stated the increased prevalence and risk of obese 229 people to coronavirus infection.230

TABREF0.text: Protocol and Registration 80This systematic review was conducted based on the Preferred Reporting Items for 81Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) Statement [15]. The protocol of this 82 systematic review has been registered in The International Prospective Register of 83 We included longitudinal cohort studies or randomised controlled trials which 87 observed the effect of BMI to the requirement of in-hospital critical care in patients 88 A systematic literature search was performed on April 12-14 th , 2020 using four 93 different databases: Cochrane, MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PubMed; along with manual 94 handsearching using keywords as listed in Table 1. Literature selection was 95 performed without time limitation but restricted to only published English or 96

TABREF1.text: All 132 studies had level 2 of evidence based on Oxford 2011 and were considered high-133 quality based on each NOS score. The results of of the critical appraisal could be 134 seen in Table 3. All studies used retrospective cohort design to explain the 135 relationship between obesity (exposure) and COVID-19 severity. While studies by 136 Simonnet et al. and Lighter J et al. used a body mass index (BMI) of more than 30 kg/m 2 to define obesity, study by Wu J, et al. used 25 kg/m 2 . These criteria were in 138 accordance with the proposed criteria for obesity in Caucasian [9] and Asian 139 population [10], respectively. 140 Using a multivariate analysis, study by Simonnet A et al. demonstrated that 141 COVID-19 patients with obesity grade II had 7.36 (1.63-33.14; p=0.021) times 142 increased risk of having invasive mechanical ventilation during in-hospital care, 143 compared to normoweight COVID-19 [19]. Meanwhile, study by Lighter J et al.
